description: To do well in this course requires a lot of reading and intellectual application. This is a hard 2xx level class. This course is an examination of politics as an activity constitutive of humanness. The course introduces students to foundational problems in political anthropology. Order, sovereignty and contestation, government, State and subject are key categories we will examine. Our first question: can there be order in the absence of a government, state, leader, sovereign? We then examine order in the context of empire and kingship, with case studies from Asia and Europe. Next, we trace the emergence of 'government' as a (modern) project of order in the political history of Europe. We look at how systems of political order are transformed during the period of Colonial rule/governance. We will then see the centrality of bureaucracy to modern governance. The second half of the course opens with inquiries into the central political forms of modern history is the 'nation' and the constitution. If constitution is one side, insurrection is its other side and we examine how both are constitutive of 'democracy'. Taking violence as an analytical object, we study the state (and its apparatuses of subjection) at the margins, treading at the limits of legality. Finally, we conclude with a discussion of the political, that is, politics as the distinction between friend and enemy. Another way to look at this course: a survey of forms of power, and the forms of subjection produced in persons subject to power. By the end of the course, students will be able to come up with a nuanced, reasoned analyses of complex problems of politics, drawing on conceptual models developed in this class.
suitable tags: political-anthropology, state-power, bureaucracy, sovereignty, subjectivity, colonialism, democracy, resistance-movements, power-relations, ethnographic-analysis, governance-theory

description: One of the many beautiful results in the theory of computation is the equivalence of "deterministic" and "non-deterministic" variants of different models of computation, like Turing machines. One may ask whether this equivalence holds if we restrict the running time (or number of steps) of a Turing machine. This gives rise to one of the most important open problems in computer science, popularly known as the P versus NP question. This will be the starting point of our course. After briefly recalling Turing machines and discussing formal definitions of the classes 'P' and 'NP', we will see the notion of 'reductions', which will allow us to talk about the 'hardest' problems in NP, known as NP-complete problems. We will discuss some important NP-complete problems from different areas like logic, graph theory, etc. After that, we will briefly talk about other important classes corresponding to the running time of a Turing machine, like 'co-NP', 'EXP', and 'NEXP'. Following this, we will see a classification of computational problems based on the space used by the Turing machine. We will discuss some important classes like PSPACE and NPSPACE (the space-variants of P and NP, respectively), their relations with P and NP, a 'PSPACE-complete' problem, the equivalence of PSPACE and NPSPACE, and other space complexity classes. Then, we will see the concept of 'polynomial hierarchy', which generalizes P, NP, and co-NP and is contained in PSPACE. If time permits, we will see a high-level introduction of randomness in computation.
suitable tags: computational-complexity, p-vs-np, turing-machines, complexity-classes, space-complexity, reductions, hard-problems, intractability, time-complexity, theoretical-computer-science

description: The origin of the study of percolation theory in 1957 was to model the flow of a liquid through a random medium. Mathematicians studied this model because it not only has an honest application, but that the questions are easy to frame, but new techniques are required to understand them. In the 1990’s application of the mathematical theory developed over the three decades were used to study wireless transmission and network topology. This course will motivate students towards formulating models to understand real-life phenomenon. description: This course aims to draw attention to logical systems that are different from classical or standard mathematical logic. These are all logics which are intended either to supplement classical logic, or else to replace it where it doesn’t fit. Such logics are grouped together under the umbrella term ‘non-classical logics’. In this course, we will cover some of these systems restricting ourselves only to the propositional cases. We will also give an introduction to analytic tableaus, which have gained popularity as a decision procedure among logicians and computer scientists. The subject could be of interest to students in both Mathematics and Computer Science. The topics covered will include a very brief review of classical propositional logic, semantic tableaus, basic modal logic, intuitionistic logic, paraconsistent and many-valued logics.

description: Sharing stories has been the most important way of communication since the early ages of mankind. According to anthropologist, Mary C. Bateson, "the human species thinks in metaphors and learns through stories." Metaphors help human's to understand abstract concepts. Humans make sense of design through the narrative function of the brain and design uses this connection to create more effectively. Storytelling is a memorable way to communicate ideas with emotional resonance. A story refers to the description provided by a narrative and exhibits a narrative structure and dramatic tension. Narratives are used in design as a technique to get insight into users, build empathy and access them emotionally. With stories, designers speak to increase the appeal of what they offer and provide a solid understanding of the users. For eg., UX designers typically tell on-screen stories, weaving narratives to make users invest their emotions in our messages. Designers aim to engage users through their feelings, as opposed to describing design of the product or system from a functionalist/task-oriented viewpoint. An effective user experience depends on the success of users’ achieving their goals ‘usability-wise’. However, storytelling is the framework used by designers to reach users. The world can be experienced through metaphors, not bullet-point specifications, storytelling is the best way to relate to audiences. Effective storytelling means going beyond getting users emotionally invested, to keeping them engaged after their experiences, too, so they attach more meaning to designed products/services. Sketching/Drawing is used as medium both to form a conceptual understanding and execution of narrative as a tool of communication. Sketching/Drawing in Visual Commuication is a fundamental tool for Narratives, which is not limited to using the analogus pencil on paper or the digital tablet and pen. It is an activity that involves observation, visualisation and storytelling.

description: Traditional economic analysis takes the rational individual as its starting point. Economic Sociology on the other hand encourages students to see rational self-interest and action as embedded in society, influenced by group dynamics, legal institutions, power, organizations and even culture. It justifies the application of independent sociological methods and concepts to the examination and understanding of the Economy as a sphere of production, consumption and exchange of goods and services, which is observable in all human societies, not only the modern and advanced. It thereby encourages students to relate economic actions to all other forms of social actions observable in society – the religious, the familial, the technological and the political. In sum, Economic sociology identifies the obligatory, symbolic and power seeking motivations underlying human economic action, not only the useful or utilitarian. Thic Course provides students with a corrective perspective. It re-ignites awareness of fundamental questions and looks to the contributions of thinkers like Karl Polanyi, Marcell Mauss and Granovetter and Swedberg to reconsider our assumptions on how we produce,consume and exchange, and live.

description: Estimation Theory is an advanced course designed for M.Tech and PhD students. This course aims to expose students to the estimation problems in a generalized manner so that they can identify, formulate and solve estimation problems. course_name: On the making of anthropological objects
description: What is it that anthropologists do? A trivial, rather disappointing answer, is that anthropologists are engaged in the creation of anthropological objects, by talking, writing, and by "doing research". This course seeks to examine how anthropological objects are made, through a careful examination of a series of case studies and through critical texts written by anthropologists on their practices of making knowledge. Although located within the intellectual history of anthropology, the course may be of value to students in allied disciplines, with an interest in problems of philosophy of knowledge. This is an advanced class and may be best suited for students already engaged in research projects. The class will be conducted as a discussion-led symposium centered around 1 or 2 scholarly texts, which are to be read before class. Attendence to the classes is mandatory for success in this course. The course begins with two contrasting anthropological works, one recent (on online poker), the other, an eighty year old classic of the discipline (on the social and political structure of an African "tribe"). Despite the obvious contrast in their objects of analysis, both these texts are "anthropologies". This course is motivated by the hypothesis that how or why something becomes an object of analytical interest for anthropology, is not at all obvious at first glance. By the end of the course, students setting out to constitute their own research problems, will be able to draw on these critical tools to examine the conditions that make possible the anthropologization of their own objects of interest.

description: The purpose of this course is to introduce the standard spatial- analytic framework for analyzing spatial data and its target audience are social scientists and engineers. In the past decade or so, much interest has grown in the area due to readily-available spatially-delineated data, particularly when in 2008 the U.S. Geological Survey stopped charging for its high-resolution LANDSAT archive. However, spatial data and spatial relationships necessitate the use of analytic tools beyond the standard statistical methods such as OLS. The role of spatial autocorrelation (also known as multidimensional autocorrelation) in spatial datasets is a focus of this course. In addition, we will ask: how and why does spatial autocorrelation arise; how is it measured and understood; how does it relate to issues of spatial heterogeneity and spatial dependence; and how these factors inform the specification and estimation of regression models. Specific modeling techniques include spatial autocorrelation measures (Moran's I, Geary's C), spatial regression models.

description: Where would you like to work? Imagine coming to IIITD or any such institution where you find your batch mates, professors and others being excited about their work. Discussions are all around the next thing that's going to change the world, the atmosphere is vibrant, lively and exciting. People are proud of their work. You see people work together, solve problems together, set standards, share ideas on how to improve performance and value diversity. You are given an opportunity to rise and shine. Now imagine the same place being very toxic, where people are very insecure, secretive, highly competitive with no cooperation etc. or a place where both of these co-exist…a sort of a hybrid So, where would you like to be? We live in a world which is more or less organized. We live most of our lives within organizations and sometimes amongst them. We grow and live in families and kin groups of different sorts, study in educational institutions, work for firms or public agencies of different sizes and shapes, join clubs, service organizations etc. and infact, if we take a moment to reflect, we would understand that a large part of our lives have been shaped by organizations. Now, getting back to the earlier question…while everyone wants to work for an ideal organisation where you have opportunities to rise and shine and come to work/study everyday in a pleasant setting…achieving this kind of a cultural setting is every leader’s dream and is easier said than done. Managing and setting ideals to create such a work culture requires understanding the various factors (both internal and external) that affect the organisation. Social and cultural influences do play a significant role more than what we tend to acknowledge. In the recent past corporations have started using ethnography and anthropology to gain insights into managing organizations strategically. Exploring and deconstructing such cultural and social influences through both fieldwork and case studies (text and videos) with a sprinkling of anthropological theories is the primary intent of this course.

description: DESIGN DRAWING : Based on the premise that drawing is central to the design process this course focuses on drawing as a medium for observing, representing, conceptualizing, visualizing and communicating design ideas. The emphasis is on drawing by hand, which is the most direct and intuitive means we have to express our visual thoughts and perceptions. In direct response to our visual thoughts and perceptions, we develop an understanding of spatial concepts and the critical ability to think and visualize in three dimensions through the tactile nature of drawing. VISUALIZATION DRAWING : Visualization is an act of thought or reflection. In design, we speculate and visualize what might be possible in the future. Drawing gives material existence to our conceptions so that they can be seen, assessed, and acted upon. The drawing out of these ideas, whether executed quickly or slowly, roughly or carefully, is necessarily speculative in nature. We can never determine beforehand precisely what the final outcome will be. The developing image on paper gradually takes on a life of its own and guides the exploration of a concept as it travels between mind and paper and back again. Drawing from the imagination addresses issues that arise as we think in a speculative manner to stimulate the design process, develop our design ideas through drawing, and plan how to present our design proposals in the best possible light. This course gives the students an overview of the generative and developmental stages of the design process and drawing as distinctly speculative in nature. Thoughts develop as a drawing progress, which can alter perceptions and suggest possibilities not yet conceived.

description: When we hear the words 'social media' we immediately think of Facebook and Twitter, WhatsApp and Instagram. But these are just platforms. Actually, Social media is the vast amount of content we have produced and its consequences for our lives. The content we produce are not just memes and selfies alone, but they are also tools for making and breaking relationships, a means for creating equality and/or reinforcing inequality. While there have been grand claims made about how social media has impacted the lives of people around the world, we often fail to ask is it really likely that social media has changed the life of a low-income builder in Brazil in exactly the same way as it has for an IT professional in South India or that of a factory worker in China? Consider this claim... social media is a sort of big brother that knows all our intimate details and we have lost our rights to privacy. While it is true for some, it is equally true that social media is also the first-time people experience privacy. For e.g. In China, for some people far from being a threat to their privacy, social media was actually the very first time they had experienced what we would call individual privacy. This was true in Turkey as well. Similarly, while it is true that while some might view social media as a distraction to education, it is equally true that for a few others social media is itself education. Likewise, for some the Selfie is more about expressing friendship rather than individual glamour, thus subverting the notion of individualism. How do we know this? Why do people see the same phenomenon differently? While it is important to understand ‘what’ content we produce, the question of why we produce such content is equally significant. This course meant as an introductory course is about ‘people’ and an attempt at understanding the affinities, connectedness, and reciprocities that social media builds. The course will also introduce ethnographic ways and means to study works of anthropologically informed social media cultures. The course would also focus on ontologies of media anthropology and specific texts that are produced through online ethnographies This course invites you to come and see for yourselves what people around the world do with social media.

description: Algorithms have always been designed to make communication systems, or for that matter any system, more reliable, less memory consuming, more efficient in using system resources, etc. This then begs the question, how does one know if an algorithm is optimal, i.e., whether it ensures the minimum possible usage of system resources in accomplishing its task? In other words, we want to ask, what are the fundamental limitations that a system and a given task imposes on all possible algorithms that can solve that given task? One possible way to tackle such questions is through the discipline of information theory, and this course is meant as an intorduction to this field. The course will broadly cover three canonical systems: The lossless storage system requiring minimal storage space consumption with perfect recovery, the noisy communication channel requiring maximum communication rates for arbitrarily low probability of decoding error, and the lossy storage system requiring minimal storage space while allowing a pre-defined level of distortion in the recovered data. To tackle these three broad problems, we shall first introduce the fundamental information theoretic quantities such as entropy, relative entropy, mutual information, and study their properties. Next, we shall introduce various tools required for proofs such as asymptotic equipartition property, Fano's inequality, method of types, data processing inequality. Finally, the student will be introduced to the probabilistic method for obtaining proofs. We shall then leverage these proof techniqes to see how the fundamental limits of the above-mentioned systems can be expressed in terms of the quantities such as entropy, relative entropy, and mutual infomation. Individual or groups of students (depending on the number of attendees) will be asked to choose and explore one further topic from a curated list of topics from areas such as network information theory, applications of information theory, information theoretic security, common information. The students would be required to prepare a report summarising their understanding of their chosen topic, as part of their evaluation.

description: The history of Ethics in the western philosophical tradition has witnessed a fundamental shift in its set of concerns and its basic approach in modernity that marks a ‘decisive break’ in relation to its point of departure in ancient Greek thought. This shift, broadly characterized, consists in moving from the question of what constitutes a ‘good life’—one that is conducive to the fullest realization of human potentiality, to what constitutes ‘right’ or ‘wrong’ action. This course will articulate and analyse the major ethical theories and approaches in the Western tradition in light of this shift. Such a broad historical perspective would allow students to apprehend why for instance, the preoccupation with the ‘Good’ gives rise to ethics of a particular ‘shape’, namely, ‘virtue ethics’; whereas the questions of ‘right’ and ‘wrong’, along with the procedural mode of their determination, emerge in the context of Enlightenment modernity, and the ‘disenchantment of nature’ that it brings in its wake. If ethics, under conditions of modernity, is compelled to take a more procedural form, as a reaction to ethical scepticism and the evisceration of ‘ethical content’ that the deracination of God from nature, hence of purposiveness in nature, entails, then the issue of what remains of the ‘old’ in the ‘new’, of the ancient in the modern, also surfaces. These themes would be pursued in different modalities, by raising, for instance, the problematic of the (privileged) ontological status of the ‘human’ (as opposed to the ‘animal’), in the modern discourse on ‘Human rights’ and environmental ethics.
suitable tags: ethics, moral-theories, utilitarianism, deontology, virtue-ethics, applied-ethics, philosophical-analysis

description: Conventional views on the global rise of populism, fake news and extreme polarisation evaluate these in terms of the 'the failure of the neoliberal economics' and/or a result of 'destabilised cultural identity'. But could this have happened without the Internet? This course offers a 'new' media perspective to answer this puzzle, and combines varied explanations to develop macro- level theoretical insights around contemporary politics and implications for policy and regulation. (In PART I) we begin by questioning the binaries in debates around 'hacktivism' which either ignore the difference between old and new media or adopts a heavy ‘technological determinism’ in their explanations. Instead, we develop arguments around the newness of Internet-enabled political action, covering key and historical and technological development relating to spatial nature of new populism ('counter public sphere' Fraser 1992), social movements (Wellman and Raini 2012) as well as communicative power (Castells 2009). (In PART II) we consider several prominent case studies and examples to evaluate these theoretical and conceptual insights. We begin with the 'occupy' movements that spread across the world after the financial crisis in early 2010s, and then analyse the use of new media in the uprisings in Arab world and Asia. Taking a series of case studies we theorise the power of Twitter, Facebook and WhatsApp as 'new' intermediaries and analyse the populist trend in terms of the changing balance between the state and society and the slow erosion of established institutions. These cases focus primarily on populist politics but also include new environmental movements, civic activism and digital journalism. In terms of pedagogical approach, and evaluating criteria, our course will rely on active learning that requires all students to develop a strong research orientation and would help them devlop independent projects that showcase these insights in terms of policy analysis, journalism as well as technology development.

It traces how cultural assumptions about the “normal” and “deficient” bodies come to be constructed and how body-altering medical technologies are used to “enhance” human form, which not only repair or replace functions, but may go beyond what is typically considered therapeutic medical intervention. description: Strictly typed data in an enterprise can be meaningfully decomposed at a fine granularity and stored in a relational database. Enterprises have gathered this information (based on the view defined) from multiple data sources and stored it in a central repository, called data warehousing, for decision support functionalities and data analysis. This kind of analysis is best-suited when the support for decision making is based on the historical or point-in-time view of the business, not on a (near) real-time view and/or knowledge. Since the “structured” data constitutes only a fraction of the entire information content within an enterprise, which also includes “unstructured” content like reports, email, meeting minutes, web-pages etc, the enterprises are now realizing to integrate their entire information sources across structured and unstructured data sources. The objective of this course is to cover the various methods of integrating homogeneous and heterogeneous information (structured/semi-structured (XML) and unstructured) through schema integration (virtual and materialized), entity extraction and matching, etc. This course will be equally focused on implementation and developing an application to demonstrate the leaned techniques for new ways to integration information. These technologies will be useful in several information integration applications domains, such as financial services, retails, telcos, social analytics, legal and compliance, and customer relationship management. These applications may require integration of information (in real-time) based on events and business policies.
suitable tags: data-integration, heterogeneous-data, semantic-web, data-fusion, linked-data, query-processing

description: The field of algorithm design has matured and grown in scope over the last sixty years - starting with the basic algorithmic questions of sorting and searching, to algorithms for problems from various disciplines; so that neary every field of human endeavour is being revolutionized by the algorithmic viewpoint. Students of this course will learn to use these modern tools irrespective of their future field of study or specialization. Also, this course attempts to give the interested students some ideas of recent trends of research in algorithm design.
suitable tags: advanced-algorithms, randomized-algorithms, approximation-algorithms, graph-algorithms, optimization

description: Analytic Number Theory is a branch of mathematics that uses analytic tools to solve number theoritic problems. It is well-known for its results on prime numbers (Prime Number Theorem and Riemann Zeta function). In this course the main aim is to study the Riemann Zeta function and its connection with the distribution of prime numbers and finally to prove the Prime Number Theorem - PNT using analytic tools.
suitable tags: analytic-number-theory, prime-distribution, zeta-functions, dirichlet-series, modular-forms, arithmetic

description: Convex optimization problems constitute an important class of optimization problems for which there is a complete mathematical theory as well as efficient algorithms. As such they have been usefully applied in diverse areas of economics, operations research and engineering. The philosophy behind the course is that an initial investment in structure theory of convex sets and functions yields rich dividends in terms of a better vision of convex (and even non-convex) optimization problems.
suitable tags: optimization-theory, convex-functions, duality-theory, mathematical-programming, convex-analysis, engineering-math

description: The aim of the course is to develop an appreciation and understanding of the processes for design of electronic instruments, gadgets and systems through a hands-on project approach. The course outcomes include (a) the ability to plan and partition the user requirement of any electronic gadget or system in smaller, manageable building blocks and then (b) implement them using contemporary available technology, including microcontrollers, sensors, input devices and output actuators in a professional enclosure with suitable user interface; (c) select and program microcontroller platforms based on user requirements (d) design suitable power supply for the system (e) debug and document the entire system.
suitable tags: circuit-design, embedded-systems, system-level-design, hardware-integration, pcb-design

description: This is a 4 credit core course for second year undegraduate ECE students. The objectives of the course is to develop problem solving skills related to transient, sinusoidal and frequency-domain circuit analysis techniques. suitable tags: circuit-theory, passive-devices, network-analysis, transient-analysis, basic-electronics

description: This course will introduce students to the evolution of processor architecture with focus on RISC V Processors. Various building blocks of RISC V processors along with their implemention using System Verilog will be discussed. Various processor architectures such as single, multi cycle and pipelined versions will be realized using system verilog and compared in terms of their performance.
suitable tags: digital-logic, processor-architecture, datapath-design, pipelining, control-units, vhdl-verilog

description: This course will enable students to evaluate urban governance practices. It draws on the ideas of 'space' and 'political power' to develop insights into the nature of urban governance and politics. With this main objective in mind, the course is broadly divided in two parts: the first part engages with the concepts of ‘space’, ‘political power’ and ‘urban governance’. The second part, introduces urban processes and events from the urban conglomeration of Delhi to empirically populate and exemplify the concepts discussed in the first half of the course. By the end of the course, the students will be able to develop an understanding of the ideas of 'space' and 'political power', and the distinctiveness of urban governance, especially in Delhi.
suitable tags: urban-politics, spatial-theory, public-policy, sociology, architecture-and-power, urban-planning

description: It is a 2 credit postgraduate level core course in advanced object oriented programming, designed to improve programming skills, and ability to use contemporary software development practices and tools. The course curriculum focuses on large software development, collaborative development environment, automatic testing and deployment, common libraries and continuous integration. It also aims to enhance the quality of design in terms of scalability and maintainability with design principles and design patterns. Along with course, students get an opportunity to learn development tools like IDEs and common frameworks.
suitable tags: object-oriented-programming, oop, software-design-patterns, class-hierarchy, java-cpp

description: Design Thinking has been recognized the world over as an important skill to successfully harness the power of non-linear, creative and empathetic approaches. Professional success in the past has largely been about replicating prior period successes into a relatively similar and predictable future. Therefore education around the world has focused on linear, analytical, and sequential thinking. However, the present we are operating in, and the future we are heading into is going to be significantly different from the past that we have come from. It is going to be more uncertain, unpredictable, and exponential, resulting in greater complexity along with exponential opportunities and exponential organizations. While logical, linear, analytical and sequential thinking will continue to be required it will not be sufficient to thrive in this future. Individuals and organizations will also need to adopt non-linear, intuitive, empathetic and creative thinking to succeed in this uncertain future. A whole new way of thinking will be required.
suitable tags: design-thinking, creativity, ideation, prototyping, entrepreneurship, user-centered-design

description: This course introduces diverse ethnographic methods and epistemologies in sociology/anthropology: participant observation, visual sources, archival documents, oral narratives, visual as well as digital resources. It exposes students to data gathering techniques, designing a research proposal, conducting structured and unstructured interviews, while at the same time introducing key debates on the conditions of producing knowledge. The course will encourage students to think reflexively while designing their research proposals, by asking how the social position of the researcher is connected to data production. Through this, questions of objectivity, interpretation, and social construction in the production of ethnographic knowledge will be explored, by bringing questions of power and the politics of representation in the production of social ‘facts’. At the end of the course, students will be able to be able to design research projects and write grant applications, while being reflexive of the location through which research is produced.
suitable tags: ethnography, qualitative-research, participant-observation, fieldwork, cultural-analysis

description: Optimal control systems is a topic that is widely used in several fields’ like transportation, aerospace bio-informatics and economics. The goal of this course is to provide advanced knowledge in formulating an optimal control problem, analyzing its properties and then solving the problem using various linear and nonlinear optimization based techniques. The course is theoretical but has implementation and problem solving components.
suitable tags: control-theory, optimization, kalman-filter, lqr, state-feedback, stability-analysis

description: This course is designed as an introduction to the theory and applications of Variational Calculus to problems in geometry, differential equations and physics, particularly mechanics. This course assumes very limited knowledge of vector calculus, ordinary differential equations and basic mechanics. Many new applications in applied mathematics, physics, chemistry, biology and engineering are included. This course will serve as a reference for advanced study and research in this subject as well as for its applications in the fields of industrial control systems and instrumentation engineering, nanoscience and software development.
suitable tags: calculus-of-variations, functional-optimization, physics-modeling, math-theory, lagrangian-methods

description: The course offers a comprehensive introduction to Ubiquitous Computing, in which the students can learn about the seamless integration of computing techniques in the environment. The course on this emerging field is focused on the basic principles, methodologies, and applications of Ubiquitous Computing. It focuses on ambient and context-aware computing, location and motion sensing, and physiological sensing. Along with the principles and methodologies of Ubiquitous Computing, the students will explore the scope and design of real-world applications that sense, process, and respond seamlessly based on the user's context. Through hands-on activities and assignments, the students will be familiarised with sensors, conceptual designs of assistive systems, data, data processing, and visualization; some of the key components of Ubiquitous Computing. The course also includes an understanding of Affective and Wearable computing through case studies, discussions, and hands-on experiments.
suitable tags: ubiquitous-computing, pervasive-systems, iot, human-computer-interaction, context-aware-computing

description: This course covers the user experience (UX design) fundamentals for XR (i.e., Augmented / Virtual/ Mixed Reality). description: This course is about providing a structured learning of digital shape representation and processing. 3D shapes around us can be acquired through various means. description: This course is a sequel to IML (MTH 300) and will begin with relational structures as interpretations for first-order languages. We will discuss the relationship between, on one hand mathematical theories, described in formal languages, and on the other, mathematical structures realizing those theories. This will be followed by detailed discussions on Gödel’s completeness theorems and its corollaries thus entering into what is known as Model Theory. We will discuss the Löwenheim-Skolem theorems, categoricity, model completeness, decidability, quantifier elimination.

description: The theory of auctions has been one of the most important successes of applied game theory. description: Popular accounts like the one by a former Google CEO of the 'new digital age' tend to underestimate the role of state institutions. This course helps to address this gap by conceptualising the rise of digital technologies in relation to the theories of power, in particular, the disruptive nature of technological change for the state. In this introductory course, we begin by considering the theoretircal foundations of the state by reviewing core concepts grounded in political science. In the first part, we conceptualize the idea of the state through diverse lenses, including international relations, political economy a well as theories of knowledge/power and the way these have conceptualized technological change. Drawing on in-depth case studies of impact of the digital, we then develop the idea of 'disruptive power' as a driving force of politics in the digital era. In the second part of the course we consider the how such 'disruptive power' is being exercised, and also resisted across various contexts. Along the way we explore the major crises in world politics, including humanitarian issues, fake news, surveillance and the impact of AI.
suitable tags: digital-politics, cyber-activism, surveillance, political-communication, data-politics, tech-policy

description: The course is an exploration of the prevailing theories, topics and empirical methods in the study of Social Psychology. description: What is the nature of mind/consciousness - is it immaterial or material, or both? How do we understand the relation between the mind, brain and the body on the one hand, and the mind and the external world, on the other? What is it to have a mental representation or a 'thought'? Are such mental representations, intentional states, and 'experiencing' itself (such as experiencing pain) inseparable from self-consiousness, such that without self-consciousness there can be no consciousness? Can 'thinking' be processively or functionally reproduced in computers? Is the possibility of such reproduction essential to fully grasping what the mind is? These are some of the issues that this course will investigate, by first situating them within the broader epistemological and ontological debates in which they arose, before turning to more contemporary approaches and theoretical responses.
suitable tags: Philosophy Core, Mind-Body Problem, Cognitive Theories, Metaphysics, Consciousness Studies, Neuroscience Interface, Epistemological Inquiry

An additional component will involve computational analysis of experimental datasets in this field to make inferences about brain and behaviour. The primary effort would be to make neural mechanisms accessible to the learners, expose them to possible applications and encourage them to find their own avenues of interest for translating the core principles of decision neuroscience.

course_name: Design for Artificial Intelligence driven Products
description: Designing for AI means designing for a human-machine relationship that is in flux; this contrasts with non-AI design where the relationship is static. AI-driven products bring together a collection of technologies (machine learning, knowledge representation and reasoning, natural language processing, computer vision, and robotics) to endow machines with increasingly human-like physical, cognitive, and emotional capabilities. AI-driven products can learn from user behavior patterns and personalize the experience of a consumer. The evolution of human-machine interactions from a context where the human adapts to the machine and the machine does not (i.e., traditional human-machine interaction), to a context where the human and the machine learn from and adapt to each other requires conceptualization about the nature of relationships consumers have with AI-driven products.

The course is mainly designed towards implementation and hence intensive programming is involved in C++ or Python. The course will use Mahindra e20 and auto-rickshaw as the hardware testbeds.

description: In recent years, Large Language Models (LLMs) have become integral to the field of Natural Language Processing (NLP), significantly enhancing the performance of essential NLP tools. This course offers a comprehensive introduction to language modeling and its diverse applications, providing a self-contained overview. Starting with the foundational probabilistic principles of language models, the course delves into the formal and theoretical aspects of what defines a language model. This all-encompassing program empowers participants with the essential knowledge and skills to effectively utilize LLMs. Covering theoretical principles and practical applications, the course provides a complete grasp of LLMs and their varied real-world applications. The course introduces recent literature in different areas related to LLMs in a seminar style. The students registering for this course should have basic knowledge in DL.

Some statistical methods have been implemented as tools while some are implemented by users according to need of data-analysis. This course would provide the basics of statistical inference and methods introducing some computational techniques to perform modelling of systems. Through this course student will also learn about weakness and strength of such statistical modelling methods which could guide them to distinguish or develop suitable analysis techniques.

description: This course covers topics in multivariable calculus, vector calculus and complex analysis. The course starts with an extension of concepts like limits, continuity and differentiation to functions of several variables. Partial differentiation is defined and applied. The idea of Taylor series is extended to functions of two variables. This is followed by a definition and application of integration in more than one dimensions: double and triple integrals. We then work with vector functions and develop the ideas of vector fields and differentiation and integration as applicable to vector calculus (gradient, divergence, curl, line and surface integrals, etc. The ideas of circulation and flux are developed and Green's, Stoke's and divergence theorems are covered. The final module of the course deals with complex numbers and functions and an extension of concepts of calculus to complex variables.
suitable tags: Core Math Course, Vector Calculus, Partial Derivatives, Double & Triple Integrals, Gradient & Divergence, Jacobian Transformations

The course also covers applications to physics and engineering.

description: The subject of topology serves to lay the foundations for future study in Analysis, in Geometry, and in Algebraic Topology. In general terms, Topology concerns itself with properties of geometric objects and mappings between them such as continuity, connectedness, compactness, deformation. In this course we study Point Set Topology which is the branch of Topology dealing with the basic set-theoretic definitions and constructions used in Topology. The core of the study will cover topological spaces, connectedness, compactness (through compactness of finite products), and the countability and separation axioms (through the Urysohn metrization theorem), and complete metric spaces. The course will prepare the student to undertake further studies in the areas mentioned above.

description: This course introduces students to sociological inquiries of science and technology. The first part traces the emergence of the scientific enterprise, with a focus on the development of the scientific disposition, and the practice of experimental science in Western Europe. The critical approach adopted here, will push students to think past realist understandings of scientific knowledge-making. The second part asks a very crucial and fundamental question— what is technology? Is technology the material artefact? Or the web of social relations in which it is developed, deployed and used? Or is technology the values that drive it, including ideas of growth, development, efficiency, reducing human labour and conquering the natural world. Through a range of case studies on electrification, high-speed rail systems, Biotechnology, etc., the course seeks to unpack the complex relationships between technology and society.

description: Fluid Mechanics is an application area of the subject of Partial Differential Equations. description: Algebraic Geometry is the study of the geometry of the solution space of a system of polynomials (or set of common zeros of the set of polynomials). description: Rising consumption levels is a key aspect of contemporary societies. “We live in a consumer society” is a phrase we come across very often. This statement points towards the disproportionate significance of material possessions, consumer goods and services in modern societies and the power of money to “buy it all”. Right from the food we eat, the clothes we wear, the cars we drive, the media we consume, the technologies we use and the health and educational services we get, consumption pervades our everyday lives and practices. Is shopping only a frivolous activity? Do people claim identities through commodities? What is modern consumption based on- needs or wants? The course on Consumer Culture and Society will make students re-think of themselves less as citizens and more as consumers. Emphasis in this course will be on understanding consumption practices by embedding them within their social, cultural, and economic contexts. Both the positive and negative impacts of consumerism on individuals and societies will be interrogated. Lectures will be complimented through field-based activities where students will examine consumption places and spaces (shopping malls, local markets, advertisements and e-stores) to understand what all (in addition to the actual product) is being sold – an image, a lifestyle, a status symbol, a body type, modernity etc.. Using specific consumption domains like food, fashion, media/entertainment technology and intimate relations the course will make the learners engage with ideas of liberation, choice, identity, status, inequality, lifestyle, freedom, signification, and power. Further, critiques of consumerism and their linkages with ‘big issues’ of consumer protests and environmental degradation will also be discussed.

description: A decision procedure is an algorithm that, given a decision problem, terminates with a correct yes/no answer. Decision procedures have been actively used in numerous applications ranging from program analysis and verification to security and constraint solving. The more popular term that describes this field is Satisfiability Modulo Theories or SMT. The technology due to the recent developments in SAT solvers has attracted researchers as well as practitioners. In this course, we will learn about theories that are expressive enough to model real problems, but are still decidable. Specifically, we will focus on decision procedures for first-order theories that are commonly used in automated verification and reasoning, theorem-proving, compiler optimization and operations research. The techniques are based on foundational topics including logic and are routinely used in industry. Therefore familiarity with first order logic as well as some experience in (preferably) C/C++ or Java programming language is assumed. At the end of the course, students will learn about SAT, DPLL, Satisfiability Modulo theories (SMT), and the DPLL(T) framework. They will study equalities and uninterpreted functions, linear arithmetic, arrays, and pointer logic. If time permits we will study the SMT applications in software engineering and/or computational biology. description: Traditionally, networking equipments consists of proprietary switching hardware with embedded software. This not only made manageability of networks complex but also stymied innovation. SDN paradigm proposed to change this, primarily by separating networking software into data and control planes. The data plane’s goal is to do switching in distributed hardware equipments. The control plane centrally governs what will be the switching rules at the data plane. As the control plane is separated from the switching hardware, it is easier to change its software, thereby speeding up software development cycle and in turn lowering the barrier for innovation. The separation of planes and centralization of control plane simplifies manageability of networks. In addition to these two benefits, SDN also facilitates network virtualization, which is a key enabler Cloud Computing. In this course, we will begin by getting familiarized to the aforementioned functions in the traditional networks. We will then learn how SDN changes the way networks will function now. We will look at open source technologies that enable deployment of SDN on real hardware and in simulation. We will see how all of networking functions, e.g. switching, routing, firewall, load balancers, and VPN, are instrumented in the new paradigm. We will explore SDN via lectures from the instructor, assignments, presentations of research papers by students, and a course project.

description: Why do we need to study about Marketing? In other words, does Marketing as a discipline really needs to be formally studied? In fact, as a discipline where does Marketing really stand at. Much like any social science discipline Marketing and its history remains evolutionary in nature. Even as sit down to write about the discipline there are changes that are happening inherently. However, much of the course and the history of it comes from Economics and the rules of it. Markets, Demand & Supply, Pricing, Competition and some more have their origins in both Economics and later Marketing also enveloped some of it. In the 80’s when the markets started opening up the new world of organised retailing and as RFID started seeping into retailing the whole texture of Marketing started to change. Consumer Behavior as a discipline emerged much more strongly and proactively, Marketing became more subjective in nature and less prone to assumptions. Simultaneously it was not only about demand generation and fulfilment. Context like impulse buying, shopping history and data driven marketing started doing the rounds. And as Digital started putting its footprint in the mid 2000’s the whole gamut of Marketing underwent massive changes.

description: Most of the software products developed today are a collection of closely coupled software applications that fulfills multiple user needs at once. Software product line paradigm is a useful approach while developing multiple software products that share common functional and quality requirements. It facilitates efficient development, production, and mass customization of software-intensive systems and software products by using a set of software subsystems and interfaces that form a common structure. However, the development and the delivery of software product is only a part of the story. Software teams should work hard to continuously improve the software applications based on the changing requirements as well as preserve them from failure of decline. While the former is called software evolution, the latter is called software maintenance. This course will guide students to develop and maintain large scale software products by providing theoretical and practical aspects of software product line paradigm as well as software evolution and maintenance.
suitable tags: code-maintenance, legacy-systems, software-evolution, software-refactoring, devops, version-control

description: Meta-Learning' or 'learning to learn' refers to the problem of developing machine learning/deep learning models that can adapt to new tasks/domains/environments, either very "rapidly", i.e., requiring very little new data/experience, or in a manner robust to distributional shifts, such as when users change their behaviour, as has been experienced across the board due to the pandemic. Both scenarios are also closely related, since distributional shifts also imply the relative scarcity of 'new' data, with practical considerations making it imperative to rapidly adapt to every 'new normal'. Meta-learning is also closely related to two long-desired goals of Al in general, viz., continual learning (without forgetting) and learning higher-level (and ideally causal) representations that allow for better generalisation, e.g. to deal with non-stationarity or for longer duration forecasting etc. In the light of the above context, the course will aim to (i) cover the basic techniques for meta-learning (ii) outline and model selected industry applications in a meta-learning setting and (iii) highlight the connections with closely related long-term Al-research goals.
suitable tags: learning-to-learn, few-shot-learning, adaptive-models, transfer-learning, hyperparameter-optimization

course_name: Smart Sensing for Internet of Things (IoT)
description: This course will introduce students to sensors and sensing systems that are in the “real-world” and are increasingly connected to the internet and are accessible via web technologies. The objective of the course is to understand IoT sensing systems, protocols and technologies. An integral part of the course will be a IoT project that the students will have to design, build and demonstrate. The ﬁnal project will span the full research cycle - from problem formulation to obtaining & analyzing results to paper writing. Speciﬁcally, the course aims to provide students with a comprehensive introduction to this area, a training in sensing mechanisms, protocols for such devices, as well as an in-depth understanding of networking mechanisms. The course will enable students to understand deployment and conﬁguration of these sensors in the real world with a focus on energy efﬁciency, challenging deployment conditions, routing and data-gathering. A substantial emphasis will be placed on software implementation. All students are expected to learn (largely on their own) how to program (hardware) and run simulations. Students are required to complete a group project as part of this course. This course also aims to train students in the craft of academic research. For this end the students will be asked to critique several papers on IoT. By the end of the course, students are expected to be able to read research papers in a critical and analytical manner. This course will be dealing with advanced topics in Internet of Things. This course is a sequel of the Internet of Things course which introduced students to basics of foundational IoT technologies. This course delves deeper into some of the technologies pertinent to IoT. Students are expected to learn by implementing protocols etc. in their programmming assignments. They will be exposed to some of the latest research findings in IoT and expected to perform thought exercises by writing research project proposals extending the frontiers of current IoT research. Finally, students will implement working prototypes of IoT systems inspired by algorithms proposed in research papers.

description: Traditionally, security to information exchange over classical communication channels has been provided by computationally complex encryption algorithms. However, given the anticipated research and development in Quantum Computers, these algorithms are at risk of being broken. Additionally, the volume of data has been exponentially rising with the introduction of new telecom services like 5G and IoT, where any compromise in the security of the ICT infrastructure will lead to a high amount of Service Level Agreements (SLA) violations, a deficit of trust and loss of valuable data. Considering these developments, there have been major efforts in developing ICT infrastructure that provides unconditional security while utilizing the fundamental laws of Quantum Mechanics. In this course, the students will be able to appreciate the aspects of Quantum Information while developing an understanding of Quantum Key Distribution (QKD) protocols which will form the basis of secured communication in the future. Further students will also learn how to apply QKD in traditional telecom infrastructure (over both fiber and wireless channels) and develop an understanding of Quantum Internet.

description: What is a city? Why is technological advancement/innovation associated with cities? Who belongs to a city? How is a city different from a countryside? Why is urban life coveted? Does Paris in France have an old city area like many Indian cities have? What makes each city different yet similar? Is everyone’s experience of living in the city the same? Urban Sociology studies the relationship between city, its institutions, its space and its people. Over the course of this semester, this course will look at (i) cities, their origin and evolution; (ii) the nature and character of cities (iii) how technology has shaped urban landscape and urban social relations; (iv) conflicts and contestations that characterise life in city; and (v) the future of cities in a digital, global age. The course will familiarise students with the macro and micro forces shaping the urban landscape and social relations. The course through a combination of lectures, case studies and activities will highlight challenges and opportunities associated with cities in a bid to encourage application of students’ technological knowledge in a sociologically relevant and socially viable manner to address urban phenomena and urban challenges. The course will broadly cover themes like urbanism, urbanisation, suburbanisation, peri-urbanisation, gentrification, slums, urban villages, segregation and inequality, right to the city, smart cities, digital technology and cities. At the culmination of this course students will broadly be familiar with ideas and debates in urban sociology.

description: You cannot be a good film maker if you don’t know how to edit audio sound track and video film footage. One of the worlds greatest film maker Eisenstein stated: "Cinematography is, first and foremost, montage." Eisenstein believed that film montage could create ideas or have an impact beyond the individual images. Two or more images edited together create a "tertium quid" (third thing) that makes the whole greater than the sum of its individual parts. Similarly Alfred Hitchcock said “For me, cinema is essentially emotion. It is pieces of film joined together that create an idea, which in turn creates an emotion in the mind of the audience. Not through spoken words, but through the visuals. It's a visual medium. And montage is the main thing. All moviemaking is pure montage." It is believed by some that good films are made more on the editing table. This course will not only give you the basic technical skills but will also hand hold you into making a aesthetically correct decisions in assembling a film

description: Computational problems can be studied from the point of view of computational resources (e.g., running time) required to solve them – this forms the notional of computational difficulty. Apart from the nature of the problem, the difficulty also depends on the underlying model of computation, including non-deterministic, non-uniform and randomized models. Problems can be related to each other based on their resource usage, and problems with similar difficulty can be grouped together to form a classification of computational problems into complexity classes. Computational complexity is about studying the above concepts, and is especially concerned with giving precise upper and lower bound on the amount of resources required to solve certain problems. This has had a profound impact on current algorithm design and cryptography, and still sees applications in areas outside of theoretical computer science.

description: This an introductory course on smooth differential forms on smooth manifolds. It will attempt to serve as a sequel to abstracting calculus beyond real and multivariable analysis to higher dimensional vector spaces and manifolds. The primary emphasis will be on understanding calculus in R^n to begin with, first for n = 3, and then more generally via differential forms. The course also has an applied theme and will conclude with three different applications of concepts: to engineering via optimization on manifolds, to mathematics via de Rham cohomology of manifolds, and to physics via modeling of Maxwell’s equations. We shall review basic concepts from multivariable calculus, linear algebra, algebra, geometry and topology first as well as intersperse them later as and when needed. Initially, this shall include geometry in linear algebra, partial and directional derivatives, multiple integrals, alternating multilinear algebra, parametric curves and surfaces, and tangent vectors and spaces. Next, we shall introduce differential forms via integration, the exterior derivative, wedge product of forms, and properties of differential forms in R^n. This will be followed by a quick discussion of Riemannian metric, the Hodge star map, and inner product of differential forms in this context. Discussion of Stoke’s theorem, an introduction to smooth manifolds, notion of vector fields, push forward and pullback maps will form the last conceptual module. In the end, we will discuss three applications, namely computational methods for linear optimization on manifolds with geometric constraints, de Rham cohomology of manifolds, and differential forms modeling of Maxwell’s equations.

description: This is an introductory course about designing solutions for computation problems using the quantum computing models. In this course a student will learn about the models and interesting solutions (circuits, algorithms) for some problems from the perspective of computer science. description: It is well known that most of the well-known optimization problems are computationally hard. It means that solving them by using a naive approach may take several years even for moderate sized input instances. Algorithms that run in polynomial-time are usually considered as feasible computation. Parameterized Complexity is an approach that attempts to extends the notion of feasible computation for NP-hard problems. The idea is to introduce a paramter in addition to the input instance for a classical problem. The running time of a algorithm allows exponential blow-up with respect to the paramter but the algorithm runs in polynomial-time otherwise. Another important part to design paramterized algorithms is polynomial-time preprocessing, also known as kernelization. Theory of parameterized preprocessing aims to build a theoretical foundations towards the greedy heuristics. One objective of this course is to understand how the basic algorithm paradigms, e.g. use of divide and conquer, dynamic programming, and greedy methods can be used to design kernelization and fixed-parameter algorithms. Another objective of this course is to understand the theory of computational intractability in the world of paramterized complexity. This objective involves expositions to parameterized complexity classes W[1], W[2] etc. and eventually designing algorithms that reduces one parameterized problem to another parameterized problem in addition to preserving the parameters. This part also involves understanding the differences between classical polynomial-time reductions and parameterized reductions. The third obejctive of this course is to understand how the classical complexity-theoretic ideas relate to the theory of lower bounds for kernelization (paramterized preprocessing).
suitable tags: FPT-algorithms, complexity-theory, kernelization, combinatorial-optimization, graph-theory-applications

description: The course aims at familiarizing the student with the concept of Financial Risk and the various instruments available for risk management. In the course of running a business, decisions are made in the presence of risk. Some risks are related to the nature of business. These risks are called business risks. Another class of risks deal with uncertainty of such factors as interest rates, exchange rates, stock prices and commodity prices. These are called financial risks. Although our financial system is replete with risks it also provides a means of dealing with these risks, in form of derivatives. Derivatives have been in existence for centuries, their growth has accelerated rapidly during the last 30 years or so. They are now used widely used by corporations, financial institutions, professional investors and individuals.
